_comment: FY2024 Survey Answer Schema - stores only answers, questions are in template
_savings: ~67% space reduction vs full markdown files

engagement_grid._comment: G1: Who was engaged and how

engagement_descriptions.people_who_use_drugs_other: Presented to sober homes and spoke to residents and listened to their concerns and what they would like for services and barriers to recovery they face.

disparities_assessment.other_methods: These needs were discussed at meetings as well as through the application process to distribute grant funds to subrecipients.

behavioral_health_assessment._comment: G3: How behavioral health needs were assessed
behavioral_health_assessment.admin_data_sources: Plymouth County Outreach provided their administrative data for overdoses/overdose follow ups/fatal overdoses when attending meetings and when requested.
behavioral_health_assessment.other_methods: Interviews were conducted by public health nurse to identify concerns over mental health conditions that needed to be addressed.
behavioral_health_assessment.barriers: Residents willingness to be open and discuss sensitive matter without a clear plan for follow up, just information gathering can be daunting to residents and seen as "a waste of time" whereas they would rather see results and actionable items.

existing_programs._comment: G4: Programs/services to leverage (mostly empty in this example)

practices.name: Alli Connect - mental health app for first responders experiencing chronic and prolonged work related stressors exacerbated by a marked increase in opioid overdoses
SAMBox Initiative - SAMBoxes with naloxone placed around the community for easy access to life saving Naloxone in places where overdoses have been recorded to occur most frequently.

planning.process: Our municipality conducted its own planning process.

treatment.barriers: Through subrecipient application, no need immediate was identified at this time. Will reassess Fall of 2024.

how_spent: Provide access to housing for people with OUD, including supportive housing, recovery housing, housing, rent, move-in deposits, and utilities assistance programs, training for housing providers, or recovery housing programs that integrate FDA-approved medication with other support services
Support or expand peer-recovery centers, which may include support groups, social events, computer access, or other services for persons with OUD

Engage non-profits, faith-based communities, and community coalitions to support people in treatment and recovery and to support family members in their efforts to support the person with OUD in the family
Support programs for recovery in schools and/or standalone recovery high schools

Support the work of Emergency Medical Systems, including peer support specialists and post-overdose response teams, to connect individuals to trauma-informed treatment recovery support, harm reduction services, primary healthcare, or other appropriate services following an opioid overdose or other opioid-related adverse event

Increase availability of naloxone and other drugs that treat overdoses for first responders, overdose patients, individuals with OUD and their friends and family, schools, community-based organizations, community navigators and outreach workers, persons being released from jail or prison, or the public
Provide training and education regarding naloxone and other drugs that treat overdoses
Other (please specify): SAMBOXes installed around community

criminal_justice.barriers: Through subrecipient application, no need immediate was identified at this time. Will reassess Fall of 2024.

pregnant_parenting.barriers: Through subrecipient application, no need immediate was identified at this time. Will reassess Fall of 2024.

prevention.barriers: Through subrecipient application, no need immediate was identified at this time. Will reassess Fall of 2024.
